name: Andromeda Galaxy (M31)
description: Nearest major galaxy to the Milky Way

name: Triangulum Galaxy (M33)
description: Third-largest member of the Local Group

name: Large Magellanic Cloud
description: Satellite galaxy of the Milky Way

name: Small Magellanic Cloud
description: Dwarf irregular galaxy satellite of the Milky Way

name: Bode's Galaxy (M81)
description: Grand design spiral galaxy

name: Cigar Galaxy (M82)
description: Starburst galaxy undergoing rapid star formation

name: Whirlpool Galaxy (M51)
description: Interacting grand-design spiral galaxy

name: Sombrero Galaxy (M104)
description: Unbarred spiral galaxy with prominent dust lane

name: Sculptor Galaxy (NGC 253)
description: Intermediate spiral galaxy in Sculptor

name: Centaurus A (NGC 5128)
description: Peculiar galaxy with distinctive dust lane

name: Orion Nebula (M42)
description: Diffuse nebula in the Milky Way, stellar nursery

name: Crab Nebula (M1)
description: Supernova remnant from 1054 AD explosion

name: Ring Nebula (M57)
description: Planetary nebula in Lyra

name: Eagle Nebula (M16)
description: Star-forming region with Pillars of Creation

name: Lagoon Nebula (M8)
description: Giant interstellar cloud in Sagittarius

name: Trifid Nebula (M20)
description: Combination of emission, reflection, and dark nebula

name: Omega Nebula (M17)
description: H II region in Sagittarius, also known as Swan Nebula

name: Helix Nebula (NGC 7293)
description: Closest planetary nebula to Earth

name: Rosette Nebula (NGC 2237)
description: Large spherical H II region

name: Horsehead Nebula (Barnard 33)
description: Dark nebula in Orion constellation

name: Pleiades (M45)
description: Open star cluster, the Seven Sisters

name: Hyades
description: Nearest open cluster to Earth

name: Omega Centauri (NGC 5139)
description: Largest globular cluster in the Milky Way

name: 47 Tucanae (NGC 104)
description: Second-brightest globular cluster

name: Hercules Cluster (M13)
description: Great globular cluster in Hercules

name: Sagittarius Cluster (M22)
description: One of the brightest globular clusters

name: Cat's Eye Cluster (M4)
description: Closest globular cluster to Earth

name: Double Cluster (NGC 869/884)
description: Pair of open clusters in Perseus

name: M35
description: Open cluster in Gemini

name: Beehive Cluster (M44)
description: Open cluster also known as Praesepe

name: Galactic Center
description: Center of the Milky Way, contains Sagittarius A*

name: North Galactic Pole
description: Direction perpendicular to galactic plane
